title: Psalms Chapter 71 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 71 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 71 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 71.

questions.question: According to Psalms 71:1, in whom does the psalmist put his trust?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:1 states, 'In thee, O LORD, do I put my trust,' indicating the psalmist trusts in the LORD.

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask God to do in Psalms 71:2?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:2 says, 'Deliver me in thy righteousness, and cause me to escape,' showing the psalmist's plea for deliverance.

questions.question: According to Psalms 71:3, what has God given commandment to do?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:3 states, 'thou hast given commandment to save me,' indicating God’s commitment to salvation.

questions.question: From whom does the psalmist ask to be delivered in Psalms 71:4?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:4 says, 'Deliver me, O my God, out of the hand of the wicked, out of the hand of the unrighteous and cruel man.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 71:5 says God is the psalmist’s hope from his youth.
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:5 states, 'For thou art my hope, O Lord GOD: thou art my trust from my youth,' confirming the truth of the statement.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 71:6: 'By thee have I been holden up from the ______.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:6 reads, 'By thee have I been holden up from the womb,' so 'womb' completes the verse correctly.

questions.question: According to Psalms 71:7, how does the psalmist describe himself to many?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:7 says, 'I am as a wonder unto many,' describing how others view the psalmist.

questions.question: What does the psalmist want to be filled with all day according to Psalms 71:8?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:8 states, 'Let my mouth be filled with thy praise and with thy honour all the day.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 71:9 asks God to forsake the psalmist in old age.
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:9 says, 'Cast me not off in the time of old age; forsake me not when my strength faileth,' so the psalmist asks not to be forsaken.

questions.question: Who do the enemies say has forsaken the psalmist according to Psalms 71:11?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:11 states, 'God hath forsaken him,' as spoken by the enemies.

questions.question: What does the psalmist request from God in Psalms 71:12?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:12 says, 'O God, be not far from me: O my God, make haste for my help,' showing the psalmist’s plea for God’s presence.

questions.question: According to Psalms 71:14, what will the psalmist do continually?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:14 says, 'But I will hope continually, and will yet praise thee more and more.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 71:17 says God has taught the psalmist from his youth.
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:17 states, 'O God, thou hast taught me from my youth,' confirming the statement.

questions.question: In Psalms 71:18, what does the psalmist ask God not to do when he is old and grayheaded?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:18 says, 'Now also when I am old and grayheaded, O God, forsake me not,' asking God not to forsake him.

questions.question: What musical instruments does the psalmist mention praising God with in Psalms 71:22?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:22 states, 'I will also praise thee with the psaltery, even thy truth, O my God: unto thee will I sing with the harp.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 71 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 71 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 71, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in difficult times?
options: God is a strong refuge and rock to trust continually
We must rely solely on our own strength
God will always remove all troubles immediately
We should isolate ourselves to avoid enemies
questions.correctAnswer: God is a strong refuge and rock to trust continually
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:3 calls God a 'strong habitation' and 'rock and fortress' where we may continually resort. Verses 7 and 14 also emphasize God as a strong refuge and the psalmist's continual hope in Him during trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 71 teach us about the importance of lifelong trust and hope in God?
options: Trusting God from youth and continuing in hope even in old age
Relying on human wisdom instead of God
Doubting God when facing old age
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God from youth and continuing in hope even in old age
questions.explanation: Verses 5 and 17 show the psalmist's trust in God from youth, and verses 9 and 18 express a plea not to be forsaken in old age, highlighting lifelong faith and hope in God.

questions.question: What does Psalms 71 teach about praising God amid difficulties?
options: Praise God continually and more and more, despite troubles
Praise only when life is easy
questions.correctAnswer: Praise God continually and more and more, despite troubles
questions.explanation: Verses 8, 14, and 23 emphasize continual praise and rejoicing in God throughout the day and even in hardship, showing praise as a vital response amid trials.

questions.question: A believer feels abandoned by God when facing persecution. Based on Psalms 71, what encouragement can you give?
options: God has not forsaken you; He is near and will deliver
You are alone and must face it yourself
Persecution means God has rejected you
questions.correctAnswer: God has not forsaken you; He is near and will deliver
questions.explanation: Verses 9-12 show the psalmist pleading not to be cast off in old age and affirming God's nearness despite enemies' accusations, encouraging trust in God's deliverance.

questions.question: How does Psalms 71 instruct believers about sharing God's righteousness and salvation?
options: Speak of God's righteousness and salvation all day long
questions.correctAnswer: Speak of God's righteousness and salvation all day long
questions.explanation: Verses 15 and 24 emphasize the psalmist's commitment to proclaim God's righteousness and salvation continually, illustrating the importance of evangelism and testimony.

questions.question: What does Psalms 71 reveal about God's role from birth through old age?
options: God has supported and taught from the womb and throughout life
Support comes from human effort only
God abandons us as we age
questions.correctAnswer: God has supported and taught from the womb and throughout life
questions.explanation: Verse 6 states God held the psalmist up from the womb, and verse 17 speaks of God's teaching from youth, showing God's lifelong guidance and support.

questions.question: How can a believer apply Psalms 71’s teaching about God’s faithfulness during hardship?
options: Trust that God will quicken and bring us up from deep troubles
Expect God to remove all troubles without struggle
Ignore God's help and rely on self
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God will quicken and bring us up from deep troubles
questions.explanation: Verse 20 promises God will quicken and bring up the psalmist from the depths, encouraging believers to trust God's faithfulness during hardships.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 71, it is appropriate to ask God for help quickly when in distress.
questions.explanation: Verse 12 explicitly pleads, 'O God, make haste for my help,' showing it is right to urgently seek God's help in distress.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 71 encourages believers to let their mouths be filled with praise and honor to God all day.
questions.explanation: Verse 8 states, 'Let my mouth be filled with thy praise and with thy honour all the day,' encouraging continuous praise.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 71 teaches us to ________ God's righteousness and salvation all day long.
questions.explanation: Verse 24 says, 'My tongue also shall talk of thy righteousness all the day long,' instructing believers to continually speak of God's righteousness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 71 illustrate the believer’s response to enemies who seek harm?
options: Pray for their confusion and shame while continuing to trust God
Avoid praying and give up hope
questions.correctAnswer: Pray for their confusion and shame while continuing to trust God
questions.explanation: Verses 10-13 describe enemies plotting harm and the psalmist asking God to confound and shame them, while expressing continued hope and praise (verse 14).

questions.question: According to Psalms 71, what role does praising God with musical instruments play in spiritual life?
options: It is a way to honor God and express truth and joy
It is only for professional musicians
questions.correctAnswer: It is a way to honor God and express truth and joy
questions.explanation: Verse 22 mentions praising God with the psaltery and harp, and verse 23 speaks of great rejoicing in singing, showing music as a form of worship and joy.

questions.question: What does Psalms 71 suggest about God’s power and works to be declared to future generations?
options: God’s strength and wondrous works should be shown to all generations
Keep God's works secret from others
questions.correctAnswer: God’s strength and wondrous works should be shown to all generations
questions.explanation: Verse 18 expresses a desire not to be forsaken in old age until God's strength is shown to this and future generations, highlighting evangelism and testimony.

questions.question: How does Psalms 71 instruct believers to view God’s righteousness?
options: As very high and worthy of praise for great things done
questions.correctAnswer: As very high and worthy of praise for great things done
questions.explanation: Verse 19 praises God's righteousness as 'very high' and recognizes the great things God has done, encouraging believers to honor His righteousness.

questions.question: What practical lesson about perseverance through trials can be learned from Psalms 71?
options: Continue to hope and praise God more and more despite adversity
Give up hope when enemies speak against you
questions.correctAnswer: Continue to hope and praise God more and more despite adversity
questions.explanation: Verse 14 underscores continual hope and increasing praise, exemplifying perseverance and faith in trials.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 71 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 71.

questions.question: In Psalms 71:3, the psalmist refers to God as his "rock and fortress." What is the significance of these metaphors in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: They signify God's unchanging nature and protection against enemies
They denote a physical temple built on a rock
They emphasize God's wrath and judgment
They imply the psalmist's physical strength
questions.correctAnswer: They signify God's unchanging nature and protection against enemies
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:3 uses the metaphors 'rock' and 'fortress' to emphasize God's steadfastness and protective power, common imagery in ancient Near Eastern literature signifying strength and refuge.

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 71 mirrors the New Testament teaching about lifelong trust in God, as seen in 2 Timothy 3:15?
options: Trusting God from youth and continuing in old age
The need to build physical temples
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God from youth and continuing in old age
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:5 and 71:18 reflect lifelong trust in God, paralleling 2 Timothy 3:15 where Timothy is taught from childhood to trust the Scriptures and God.

questions.question: Psalms 71:6 states, "By thee have I been holden up from the womb." What Hebrew concept does this express?
options: Divine providence and sustaining care from birth
questions.correctAnswer: Divine providence and sustaining care from birth
questions.explanation: The verse highlights God's providential care beginning in the womb, emphasizing the intimate relationship between God and the psalmist from birth, a theme common in Hebrew thought.

questions.question: In Psalms 71:9, the psalmist pleads, "Cast me not off in the time of old age." How does this relate to the cultural value of elders in ancient Israel?
options: It reflects the desire to maintain honor and support in old age
It shows a rejection of elders' wisdom
It demands isolation for the aged
It encourages abandonment of the elderly
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the desire to maintain honor and support in old age
questions.explanation: Ancient Israel highly valued elders for their wisdom; Psalms 71:9 requests God's continued presence, reflecting cultural respect and dependence on divine favor in later years.

questions.question: Which literary device is predominantly used in Psalms 71:14, "But I will hope continually, and will yet praise thee more and more"?
questions.explanation: The verse uses synonymous parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, repeating the theme of hope and praise for emphasis.

questions.question: Psalms 71:20 mentions "great and sore troubles" from which God will "quicken me again." What New Testament concept does this foreshadow?
questions.explanation: The psalm’s mention of revival from deep troubles prefigures the New Testament teaching of resurrection and life through Jesus (e.g., John 11:25).

questions.question: In Psalms 71:22, the psalmist promises to praise God with the psaltery and harp. What does this reveal about Israelite worship practices?
options: Music was integral to worship and praise
Worship was silent and without instruments
questions.correctAnswer: Music was integral to worship and praise
questions.explanation: The mention of musical instruments in verse 22 reflects the ancient Israelite tradition of incorporating music into worship, seen throughout the Psalms.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 71 expresses confidence that God will not forsake the psalmist even in old age when strength fails.
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:9 and 71:18 explicitly express the psalmist’s plea that God will not abandon him in old age or when his strength fails.

questions.question: Which aspect of God’s character is most emphasized throughout Psalms 71?
questions.explanation: The psalm consistently highlights God's role as a protector, refuge, and faithful helper (e.g., verses 3, 5, 7, 14).

questions.question: In Psalms 71:11, the enemies say, "God hath forsaken him." What theological theme does this challenge relate to?
options: The problem of divine abandonment and faith under trial
questions.correctAnswer: The problem of divine abandonment and faith under trial
questions.explanation: The enemies accuse the psalmist of being forsaken by God, illustrating the challenge of maintaining faith amidst suffering and apparent divine silence.

questions.question: Psalms 71:15 mentions, "My mouth shall shew forth thy righteousness and thy salvation all the day; for I know not the numbers thereof." What does the phrase "I know not the numbers thereof" imply?
options: God's salvation is too vast to count
The psalmist is confused about God's acts
questions.correctAnswer: God's salvation is too vast to count
questions.explanation: The phrase indicates the psalmist’s recognition of the innumerable acts of salvation God has performed, emphasizing God’s abundant grace.

questions.question: Which Old Testament book similarly emphasizes lifelong trust in God from youth to old age, paralleling Psalms 71?
questions.explanation: Proverbs 22:6 and 4:1-4 emphasize teaching and trusting God from youth, paralleling the lifelong trust theme in Psalms 71.

questions.question: Psalms 71:17 states, "O God, thou hast taught me from my youth." What does this reveal about the psalmist’s understanding of divine instruction?
options: Divine teaching is a lifelong process beginning early
God only teaches in old age
Human wisdom is sufficient without God
questions.correctAnswer: Divine teaching is a lifelong process beginning early
questions.explanation: The psalmist acknowledges the continuous guidance from God starting in youth, emphasizing the importance of early and ongoing divine instruction.

questions.question: The plea in Psalms 71:12, "O God, be not far from me: O my God, make haste for my help," uses what Hebrew literary technique?
questions.explanation: The verse employs synonymous parallelism, repeating the idea of God’s nearness and swift help in two synonymous phrases.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Psalms 71:4, the psalmist asks God to deliver him from the hand of the wicked, the unrighteous, and the _____ man.
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:4 specifically mentions deliverance from the wicked, the unrighteous, and the cruel man.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 71 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 71 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 71:3, how is God described in relation to the believer?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:3 explicitly calls God 'my rock and my fortress,' emphasizing His role as a strong, protective refuge. This aligns with other scriptures like 2 Samuel 22:2-3 and Psalm 18:2, which portray God as a rock and fortress, symbolizing His strength and protection. Isaiah 26:4 calls God an everlasting rock, and 1 Corinthians 10:4 refers to Christ as the spiritual rock.

questions.question: What does the psalmist request God not to do in old age according to Psalms 71:9?
questions.explanation: In Psalms 71:9, the psalmist pleads, 'Cast me not off in the time of old age,' showing a deep trust in God's continual care throughout life. This is consistent with Isaiah 46:4, which promises God's support even in old age, and 2 Corinthians 12:9, where God’s grace is sufficient in weakness. Psalm 92:12-14 also speaks of fruitfulness in old age.

questions.question: In Psalms 71:5, how does the psalmist describe his relationship with God from youth?
options: Thou art my trust from my youth
Thou art my teacher and guide
Thou art my redeemer from youth
Thou art my strength and shield
questions.correctAnswer: Thou art my trust from my youth
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:5 states, 'thou art my trust from my youth,' highlighting lifelong reliance on God. This echoes Deuteronomy 11:19 which teaches to remember God’s commands from youth, and 2 Timothy 3:15 which praises the sacred writings making one wise unto salvation from childhood. Proverbs 22:6 also encourages training children in the way they should go.

questions.question: What does the psalmist say God has done for him from the womb, according to Psalms 71:6?
options: Holden me up and taken me out of my mother's bowels
Written my name in the book of life
questions.correctAnswer: Holden me up and taken me out of my mother's bowels
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:6 declares God's sustaining presence from the womb, 'By thee have I been holden up... thou art he that took me out of my mother's bowels.' This corresponds to Psalm 139:13-16 which speaks of God's involvement in our formation in the womb, Jeremiah 1:5 where God knew Jeremiah before birth, and Luke 1:44 illustrating prenatal recognition of God's work.

questions.question: According to Psalms 71:14, what attitude does the psalmist commit to despite adversity?
options: Hope continually and praise more and more
questions.correctAnswer: Hope continually and praise more and more
questions.explanation: In Psalms 71:14, the psalmist affirms continual hope and increasing praise despite trials. This echoes Romans 12:12 urging believers to hope and be patient in tribulation, Hebrews 10:23 encouraging holding fast the confession of hope, and Philippians 4:4 commanding rejoicing always. 1 Thessalonians 5:16-18 also calls for continual joy and prayer.

questions.question: How does Psalms 71:20 describe the troubles God has shown the psalmist and His response?
options: Great and sore troubles; God shall quicken and bring me up again
Minor trials; God will leave me to suffer
Only blessings; no troubles have come
Unbearable hardships; God has forsaken me
questions.correctAnswer: Great and sore troubles; God shall quicken and bring me up again
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:20 acknowledges severe troubles but affirms God's power to revive and restore. This resonates with Job 14:14’s hope in resurrection, Isaiah 53:4-5 about suffering leading to healing, Romans 8:28 about all things working together for good, and 2 Corinthians 4:8-9 describing resilience through affliction.

questions.question: What instrument does the psalmist mention using to praise God in Psalms 71:22?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:22 says, 'I will also praise thee with the psaltery... unto thee will I sing with the harp.' This reflects the biblical tradition of musical worship seen in 1 Chronicles 15:16 where David appoints singers with psalteries and harps, Psalm 33:2 encouraging praise with harp and lyre, and Ephesians 5:19 urging believers to sing psalms with gratitude.

questions.question: In Psalms 71:16, the psalmist declares he will go in the strength of whom?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:16 affirms reliance on 'the strength of the Lord GOD,' highlighting divine empowerment. This aligns with Isaiah 40:31 promising renewed strength to those who wait on the LORD, Philippians 4:13 stating 'I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me,' and Exodus 15:2 calling the LORD strength and salvation.

questions.question: Who are described as the adversaries in Psalms 71:13, and what is their fate?
options: Those who seek my hurt; confounded and consumed
questions.correctAnswer: Those who seek my hurt; confounded and consumed
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:13 prays for adversaries who aim to harm the psalmist to be 'confounded and consumed.' This is consistent with Psalm 37:20 where evildoers perish, Proverbs 11:21 which states wickedness leads to destruction, Romans 12:19 instructing vengeance to God, and Revelation 20:10 describing final judgment on evil.

questions.question: What is the psalmist’s attitude toward God’s righteousness as expressed in Psalms 71:15?
options: My mouth shall show forth thy righteousness and salvation all the day
questions.correctAnswer: My mouth shall show forth thy righteousness and salvation all the day
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:15 commits to continual proclamation of God's righteousness and salvation. This reflects Psalm 89:15 which speaks of righteousness and praise in the upright, Isaiah 61:10 rejoicing in God’s salvation and righteousness, Romans 1:16 declaring the gospel as the power of God for salvation, and 2 Timothy 4:2 commanding preaching the word.

questions.question: According to Psalms 71:11, what do the enemies say about the psalmist's relationship with God?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:11 records the enemies’ claim that 'God hath forsaken him,' a common accusation against the faithful in trials (Psalm 22:1, Job 13:23-24). The psalmist’s faith contrasts this with Jesus’ cry on the cross and the ultimate vindication of God's people in Romans 8:31-39 and Hebrews 13:5.

questions.question: What does Psalms 71:18 reveal about the psalmist’s desire in old age?
options: To show God's strength to the next generation
questions.correctAnswer: To show God's strength to the next generation
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:18 expresses a desire to declare God's strength and power to future generations, reflecting Deuteronomy 6:7 which commands teaching children, Psalm 78:4’s emphasis on passing down God’s deeds, and 2 Timothy 4:2 encouraging faithful proclamation at all times.

questions.question: In Psalms 71:12, what does the psalmist ask God to do in response to his distress?
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:12 implores God to 'make haste for my help,' expressing urgency in deliverance. This is consistent with Psalm 40:13, where the psalmist asks God not to delay, Lamentations 3:25-26 on waiting patiently for the LORD, and Hebrews 4:16 encouraging confident approach to God's throne for mercy.

questions.question: What does the psalmist say his mouth shall be filled with, according to Psalms 71:8?
options: Thy praise and honour all the day
questions.correctAnswer: Thy praise and honour all the day
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:8 desires that the mouth be filled with praise and honour continually, aligning with Psalm 34:1 which calls to bless the LORD at all times, Psalm 145:2 about daily praising God’s name, and Ephesians 5:19 encouraging speaking to one another with psalms and hymns.

questions.question: What is the psalmist’s declaration about his lips and soul in Psalms 71:23?
options: My lips shall greatly rejoice when I sing unto thee; and my soul, which thou hast redeemed
My lips are silent and my soul is troubled
My lips speak lies and my soul is lost
My lips mourn and my soul is faint
questions.correctAnswer: My lips shall greatly rejoice when I sing unto thee; and my soul, which thou hast redeemed
questions.explanation: Psalms 71:23 expresses joy in singing unto God and gratitude for redemption of the soul, consistent with Psalm 103:1-2 praising God with all heart, Isaiah 61:1-3 proclaiming the year of the LORD’s favor, and Ephesians 1:7 which speaks of redemption through Christ’s blood.
